grammar.name: Subject-Verb-Object (SVO)
grammar.description_en: The basic sentence structure in Mandarin. Subject comes first, then verb, then object. Unlike French, adjectives typically precede nouns without agreement.
grammar.description_fr: La structure de phrase de base en mandarin. Sujet d'abord, puis verbe, puis objet.

examples.english: I am a student.
He is French.

grammar.name: Negation with 不 (bù)
grammar.description_en: To negate most verbs and adjectives, place 不 (bù) directly before them. The tone changes to 2nd tone (bú) before 4th tone words.
grammar.description_fr: Pour nier un verbe ou un adjectif, placez 不 (bù) directement avant. Le ton change en 2ème ton devant un mot en 4ème ton.

examples.english: I am not a teacher.
I don't drink coffee.

grammar.name: Adjectival predicate with 很 (hěn)
grammar.description_en: In Chinese, adjectives can directly function as predicates without a copula (是). However, 很 is typically added before the adjective, not necessarily meaning "very" but acting as a linking element.
grammar.description_fr: En chinois, les adjectifs peuvent directement servir de prédicats sans copule. 很 est ajouté devant l'adjectif comme élément de liaison.

examples.english: She is beautiful.
Chinese is difficult.

grammar.name: Question particle 嗎 (ma)
grammar.description_en: Add 嗎 at the end of any statement to turn it into a yes/no question. The sentence structure stays the same — only 嗎 is appended.
grammar.description_fr: Ajoutez 嗎 à la fin de n'importe quelle phrase déclarative pour la transformer en question oui/non.

examples.english: Are you a student?
Do you like Chinese?

grammar.name: Possession with 的 (de)
grammar.description_en: The particle 的 indicates possession, similar to apostrophe-s in English. It links possessor to the possessed noun.
grammar.description_fr: La particule 的 indique la possession, similaire au génitif saxon en anglais.

examples.english: my book
the teacher's name

examples.pinyin: Wǒ de Zhōngwén lǎoshī hěn hǎo.
examples.english: My Chinese teacher is very good.

grammar.name: Time expressions before verb
grammar.description_en: In Mandarin, time words (today, tomorrow, now) come before the verb, not after as in French. They can also appear at the very beginning of the sentence.
grammar.description_fr: En mandarin, les expressions de temps se placent avant le verbe, contrairement au français où elles viennent souvent après.

examples.english: I study Chinese today.
Where are you going tomorrow?

grammar.name: A-not-A Questions
grammar.description_en: The A-not-A form is the most neutral way to ask yes/no questions in Chinese. The first verbal element is repeated in its negative form (V 不 V). When the verb is disyllabic (XY), the pattern can be shortened to X + 不 + XY.
grammar.description_fr: La forme A-pas-A est la façon la plus neutre de poser des questions oui/non en chinois. Le premier élément verbal est répété sous forme négative (V 不 V). Quand le verbe est dissyllabique (XY), la structure peut être raccourcie en X + 不 + XY.

examples.pinyin: Wáng Xiānshēng yào bú yào hē kāfēi?
examples.english: Does Mr. Wang want to have some coffee?

examples.pinyin: Nǐ shì bú shì Rìběn rén?
examples.english: Are you Japanese?
Is he coming to Taiwan?

grammar.name: Questions with 嗎
grammar.description_en: Questions can be formed by adding the particle 嗎 at the end of a statement. It is usually used for short or simple questions. Unlike A-not-A questions, 嗎 questions cannot be combined with A-not-A form in the same sentence.
grammar.description_fr: Les questions peuvent être formées en ajoutant la particule 嗎 à la fin d'une phrase déclarative. Elle est généralement utilisée pour des questions courtes ou simples. Contrairement aux questions A-pas-A, les questions en 嗎 ne peuvent pas être combinées avec la forme A-pas-A.

examples.english: How are you?
Is he Japanese?
Do you want to drink tea?

grammar.name: Negative Replies with 不
grammar.description_en: Negative replies are formed by placing 不 before the main verb. 不 is an adverb placed before a verb or another adverb. For short answers, repeating just 不 + verb from the question suffices.
grammar.description_fr: Les réponses négatives se forment en plaçant 不 avant le verbe principal. 不 est un adverbe placé avant un verbe ou un autre adverbe. Pour les réponses courtes, répéter simplement 不 + verbe de la question suffit.

examples.pinyin: Bú shì, tā bú shì Lǐ Xiānshēng.
examples.english: No, he is not Mr. Li.
No, he doesn't drink (tea).

grammar.name: Modification Marker 很
grammar.description_en: The adverb 很 modifies state verbs (adjectives). In Chinese, adjectival state verbs must generally be preceded by either 不 or an intensifier like 很. When no special intensity is intended, 很 is used as a default modifier and may simply mean the state verb without emphasizing 'very'.
grammar.description_fr: L'adverbe 很 modifie les verbes d'état (adjectifs). En chinois, les verbes d'état adjectivaux doivent généralement être précédés de 不 ou d'un intensificateur comme 很. Quand aucune intensité particulière n'est voulue, 很 est utilisé par défaut et peut simplement signifier le verbe d'état sans insister sur 'très'.

examples.english: I am fine.
Oolong tea tastes good.
He likes Taiwan.

grammar.name: Contrastive Questions with 呢
grammar.pattern: S1 V O, S2 呢? / S V O1, O2 呢?
grammar.description_en: The 呢 question is a tag question used after a statement to ask about a contrasting subject or object. It can be used with the same predicate and different subjects, or the same subject with different objects/predicates.
grammar.description_fr: La question en 呢 est une question tag utilisée après une déclaration pour interroger sur un sujet ou objet contrastif. Elle peut s'utiliser avec le même prédicat et des sujets différents, ou le même sujet avec des objets/prédicats différents.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ yào hē chá, nǐ ne?
examples.english: I want to drink tea, and you?

examples.chinese: 王先生是日本人，李先生呢？
examples.pinyin: Wáng Xiānshēng shì Rìběn rén, Lǐ Xiānshēng ne?
examples.english: Mr. Wang is Japanese. What about Mr. Li?

grammar.name: Possessive Marker 的
grammar.description_en: 的 is placed between the possessor and the object possessed to show possession. 的 can be omitted when the relationship between the two nouns is close (e.g., family members) and the possessor is a pronoun. 的 cannot be omitted when the possessor is a proper noun or a full noun phrase.
grammar.description_fr: 的 est placé entre le possesseur et l'objet possédé pour exprimer la possession. 的 peut être omis quand la relation entre les deux noms est étroite (ex. membres de la famille) et que le possesseur est un pronom. 的 ne peut pas être omis quand le possesseur est un nom propre ou un syntagme nominal complet.

examples.english: my book
Teacher Li's older sister
my mom (的 omitted)

grammar.name: Modifier Marker 的 (adjective + noun)
grammar.description_en: 的 is used between a modifier (adjective or descriptive phrase) and the head noun it modifies. 的 can be omitted when the modifier and noun are used together very frequently, such as nationality expressions (臺灣人 not 臺灣的人).
grammar.description_fr: 的 est utilisé entre un modificateur (adjectif ou phrase descriptive) et le nom principal qu'il modifie. 的 peut être omis quand le modificateur et le nom sont très fréquemment utilisés ensemble, comme les expressions de nationalité (臺灣人 et non 臺灣的人).

examples.english: pretty young lady
beautiful house
tasty coffee

grammar.name: Possession with 有 and negation with 沒有
grammar.pattern: S + 有 + O / S + 沒有 + O
grammar.description_en: The verb 有 expresses possession or ownership. Unlike most verbs in Chinese, 有 is always negated with 沒 (not 不). Questions use the A-not-A form 有沒有 or the 嗎 particle.
grammar.description_fr: Le verbe 有 exprime la possession. Contrairement à la plupart des verbes en chinois, 有 se nie toujours avec 沒 (pas avec 不). Les questions utilisent la forme A-pas-A 有沒有 ou la particule 嗎.

examples.english: I have many photos.
He does not have a house.

examples.pinyin: Nǐ yǒu méi yǒu xiōngdì jiěmèi?
examples.english: Do you have any brothers or sisters?

grammar.name: Totality Adverb 都
grammar.description_en: 都 indicates that all items referred to by the subject share a common quality or action. It is an adverb placed after the noun(s) it relates to and before the main verb. All members of the group must appear before 都. In negation, 都不/沒 means 'none', while 不都 means 'not all'.
grammar.description_fr: 都 indique que tous les éléments référencés par le sujet partagent une qualité ou action commune. C'est un adverbe placé après le(s) nom(s) auquel il se rapporte et avant le verbe principal. Tous les membres du groupe doivent apparaître avant 都. En négation, 都不/沒 signifie 'aucun', tandis que 不都 signifie 'pas tous'.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ jiārén dōu hěn xǐhuān zhàoxiàng.
examples.english: My family all like to take photos.

examples.pinyin: Wǒmen dōu bú shì Měiguó rén.
examples.english: None of us is American.

examples.chinese: 這兩張照片都是我姐姐的。
examples.pinyin: Zhè liǎng zhāng zhàopiàn dōu shì wǒ jiějie de.
examples.english: Both of these two photos are my older sister's.

grammar.name: Measure Words 個 and 張
grammar.description_en: In Chinese, a measure word must be placed between a number and a noun. 個 is the most general measure word used for people and many objects. 張 is used for flat objects like paper, photos, and tables. When the number is two, 兩 is used instead of 二 before measure words.
grammar.description_fr: En chinois, un classificateur doit être placé entre un nombre et un nom. 個 est le classificateur le plus général, utilisé pour les personnes et de nombreux objets. 張 est utilisé pour les objets plats comme le papier, les photos et les tables. Quand le nombre est deux, 兩 est utilisé à la place de 二 avant les classificateurs.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ jiā yǒu wǔ gè rén.
examples.english: There are five people in my family.
two pretty photos
How many teachers?

grammar.name: Placement of Time Words
grammar.pattern: Time Word + S + VP  /  S + Time Word + VP
grammar.description_en: Time words in Chinese can appear either before or after the subject, but always before the verb phrase. Units of time are ordered from largest to smallest (e.g., weekend → morning, not morning → weekend).
grammar.description_fr: Les mots de temps en chinois se placent avant ou après le sujet, mais toujours avant le groupe verbal. Les unités de temps s'ordonnent du plus grand au plus petit (ex. week-end → matin, pas l'inverse).

examples.english: We are going to see a movie today.

examples.pinyin: Zhōumò tā yào qù dǎ lánqiú.
examples.english: This weekend he is going to play basketball.

examples.chinese: 明天晚上我們看什麼電影？
examples.pinyin: Míngtiān wǎnshàng wǒmen kàn shénme diànyǐng?
examples.english: What movie are we watching tomorrow evening?

grammar.name: 去 + VP (going to do something)
grammar.description_en: 去 (qù) followed by a verb phrase expresses the intention to go somewhere in order to do something. Negation markers, auxiliary verbs, and adverbs are placed before 去, not before the main verb.
grammar.description_fr: 去 (qù) suivi d'un groupe verbal exprime l'intention d'aller faire quelque chose. Les marqueurs de négation, les auxiliaires et les adverbes se placent avant 去, pas avant le verbe principal.

examples.english: I am going to go play tennis.

examples.pinyin: Míngtiān zǎoshàng wǒ bù qù yóuyǒng.
examples.english: I am not going to go swimming tomorrow morning.

examples.pinyin: Nǐmen cháng qù chī Yuènán cài ma?
examples.english: Do you often go eat Vietnamese food?

grammar.name: Topic-Comment Sentences with 都
grammar.description_en: A topic is placed at the very beginning of the sentence to frame what is being discussed. The rest of the sentence is the comment. When the fronted topic is a collective noun or multiple nouns, the totality marker 都 (dōu) is required in the comment.
grammar.description_fr: Le thème est placé en tête de phrase pour cadrer le sujet. Le reste constitue le commentaire. Quand le thème est un nom collectif ou plusieurs noms, le marqueur de totalité 都 (dōu) est obligatoire dans le commentaire.

examples.chinese: 美國電影、臺灣電影，我都想看。
examples.pinyin: Měiguó diànyǐng, Táiwān diànyǐng, wǒ dōu xiǎng kàn.
examples.english: American movies, Taiwanese movies — I want to watch both.
Playing baseball, I don't like it.
Younger brothers and sisters — I have both.

grammar.name: Word Order of 也, 都, and 常
grammar.pattern: S + 也 / 都 / 常 + VP  (when combined: 也 precedes 都 or 常)
grammar.description_en: 也 (yě), 都 (dōu), and 常 (cháng) are adverbs that always appear before the verb. When 也 co-occurs with 都 or 常, 也 must come first. In negation, 也 precedes the negation marker 不/沒, while 常 follows 不.
grammar.description_fr: 也 (yě), 都 (dōu) et 常 (cháng) sont des adverbes qui se placent toujours avant le verbe. Quand 也 coexiste avec 都 ou 常, 也 vient en premier. En négation, 也 précède 不/沒, tandis que 常 suit 不.

examples.chinese: 我常打網球，也常踢足球。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ cháng dǎ wǎngqiú, yě cháng tī zúqiú.
examples.english: I often play tennis and also often play soccer.

examples.chinese: 你常去踢足球，我們也都常去踢足球。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ cháng qù tī zúqiú, wǒmen yě dōu cháng qù tī zúqiú.
examples.english: You often go play soccer; we also all often go play soccer.
I don't watch movies often.

grammar.name: Making Suggestions with 吧
grammar.description_en: The sentence-final particle 吧 (ba) softens a statement into a suggestion or mild imperative. It is placed at the very end of the sentence. Without 吧, an imperative sounds harsh and direct.
grammar.description_fr: La particule finale 吧 (ba) transforme un énoncé en suggestion ou impératif atténué. Elle se place en toute fin de phrase. Sans 吧, un impératif est perçu comme brusque et peut sembler impoli.

examples.english: Let's go drink coffee.
Let's watch a Taiwanese movie.
Let's play tennis!

grammar.name: Measure Words: 塊, 杯, 支, 種
grammar.pattern: Number + Measure Word + Noun  /  Det + (Number) + Measure Word + Noun
grammar.description_en: A measure word is required between a number (or determiner) and a noun. 塊 (kuài) is used for money, 杯 (bēi) for cups of liquid, 支 (zhī) for long thin objects like phones, and 種 (zhǒng) for kinds or types. When a determiner like 這/那/哪 is used, the numeral 一 (yī) is typically omitted.
grammar.description_fr: Un classificateur est obligatoire entre un nombre (ou un déterminant) et un nom. 塊 (kuài) s'utilise pour l'argent, 杯 (bēi) pour les boissons, 支 (zhī) pour les objets longs et fins comme les téléphones, et 種 (zhǒng) pour les types ou sortes. Quand un déterminant comme 這/那/哪 est utilisé, le numéral 一 (yī) est généralement omis.

examples.chinese: 這兩杯熱咖啡一共多少錢？
examples.pinyin: Zhè liǎng bēi rè kāfēi yīgòng duōshǎo qián?
examples.english: How much in total for these two cups of hot coffee?

examples.pinyin: Nà sān zhī shǒujī tài jiù le.
examples.english: Those three cell phones are too old.
Which type of cell phone is not expensive?

grammar.name: 幫 as Beneficiary Preposition
grammar.description_en: The preposition 幫 (bāng) introduces the person who benefits from an action, equivalent to 'for someone' in English. Negation is placed before 幫, not before the main verb.
grammar.description_fr: La préposition 幫 (bāng) introduit le bénéficiaire d'une action, équivalent à 'pour quelqu'un' en français. La négation se place avant 幫, pas avant le verbe principal.

examples.english: Please microwave the baozi for me.

examples.pinyin: Tā bù bāng wǒ mǎi kāfēi.
examples.english: He won't buy coffee for me.

examples.pinyin: Shéi néng bāng Āntóng wēibō bāozi?
examples.english: Who can microwave a baozi for Antong?

grammar.name: 的-Phrase with Head Noun Omitted
grammar.description_en: When a modified noun is clear from context, the head noun can be omitted after 的 (de), leaving just the modifier + 的 to stand as a noun phrase. This is used to avoid repetition and is common in answering questions.
grammar.description_fr: Quand le nom modifié est évident dans le contexte, le nom principal peut être omis après 的 (de), laissant modificateur + 的 fonctionner comme un groupe nominal. Cela permet d'éviter les répétitions et est courant dans les réponses.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ yào xīn de, bù yào jiù de.
examples.english: I want a new one. I don't want an old one.
New ones are expensive.

examples.chinese: 這杯咖啡不熱，我要熱的。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bēi kāfēi bù rè, wǒ yào rè de.
examples.english: This cup of coffee is not hot. I want a hot one.

grammar.name: 太…了 (too / overly)
grammar.description_en: 太 (tài) + Vs means 'too' or 'overly' adjective. Adding 了 (le) at the end makes the expression more subjective, emphasizing the speaker's sense that something is excessively so. 太 + Vs alone (without 了) is slightly less emphatic but still expresses excess.
grammar.description_fr: 太 (tài) + adjectif signifie 'trop'. Ajouter 了 (le) à la fin rend l'expression plus subjective, soulignant le sentiment du locuteur que quelque chose est excessif. 太 + adjectif seul (sans 了) est légèrement moins emphatique mais exprime aussi l'excès.

examples.pinyin: Nà zhī shǒujī tài guì le.
examples.english: That cell phone is way too expensive.
Too big.

examples.chinese: 我這支手機太舊了，不好看。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zhè zhī shǒujī tài jiù le, bù hǎokàn.
examples.english: This cell phone of mine is too old. It's unattractive.

grammar.name: 能 for Capability
grammar.description_en: The auxiliary verb 能 (néng) expresses capability or ability of the subject. Negation 不 is placed before 能, not after. In A-not-A questions, 能 is placed in the A position: 能不能 + VP.
grammar.description_fr: L'auxiliaire 能 (néng) exprime la capacité ou l'aptitude du sujet. La négation 不 se place avant 能, pas après. Dans les questions A-non-A, 能 se place en position A : 能不能 + VP.

examples.english: New cell phones can go online.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ de shǒujī bù néng zhàoxiàng.
examples.english: My cell phone cannot take pictures.

examples.pinyin: Nǐ de shǒujī néng bu néng shàngwǎng?
examples.english: Can your cell phone go online?

grammar.name: 多 for 'and more / over'
grammar.description_en: 多 (duō) placed after a round number indicates 'more than' or 'over' that amount, but less than the next round number. When used after numbers ≥10, it indicates the residual unspecified amount. When used after single digits or small numbers, it means 'a bit more than' that figure.
grammar.description_fr: 多 (duō) placé après un nombre rond indique 'plus de' ce montant, mais moins que le nombre rond suivant. Après des nombres ≥ 10, il indique le reste non précisé. Après de petits chiffres, il signifie 'un peu plus que' ce chiffre.

examples.english: over 20 people (but under 30)
over 1,000 cell phones (but under 2,000)

examples.pinyin: Yī zhī yào yīwàn wǔqiān duō.
examples.english: One costs over NT$15,000.

grammar.title: 有一點 yǒu yìdiǎn — slightly negative degree
grammar.explanation: 有一點 (yǒu yìdiǎn) means 'a little' or 'slightly' and conveys a mildly negative evaluation. It can only precede state verbs with negative or neutral connotations — it cannot be used with positive adjectives like 漂亮 (pretty). There is no negative form of this pattern.

examples.chinese: 這碗牛肉麵有一點辣，可是很好吃。
examples.pinyin: Zhè wǎn niúròu miàn yǒu yìdiǎn là, kěshì hěn hǎochī.
examples.english: This bowl of beef noodles is a little spicy, but delicious.
examples.french: Ce bol de nouilles au bœuf est un peu épicé, mais délicieux.

examples.chinese: 那家餐廳的菜有一點貴，可是真的很好吃。
examples.pinyin: Nà jiā cāntīng de cài yǒu yìdiǎn guì, kěshì zhēn de hěn hǎochī.
examples.english: The food at that restaurant is a little expensive, but really delicious.
examples.french: La nourriture de ce restaurant est un peu chère, mais vraiment délicieuse.

grammar.title: Complement Marker 得 de
grammar.pattern: Verb + 得 + Complement / Verb + Object + Verb + 得 + Complement
grammar.explanation: 得 (de) follows a verb to introduce a complement describing how well or to what degree the action was performed. When the verb is transitive and takes an object, the verb must be repeated before 得: e.g., 做飯做得很好. Negation occurs inside the complement only: 做得不好. If the object appears at the front of the sentence (topic-comment), the verb is not repeated: 飯，他做得很好.

examples.chinese: 她做飯做得很好，大家都說好吃。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuòfàn zuò de hěn hǎo, dàjiā dōu shuō hǎochī.
examples.english: She cooks very well — everyone says it's delicious.
examples.french: Elle cuisine très bien — tout le monde dit que c'est délicieux.

examples.pinyin: Zhōngwén, nǐ shuō de hǎo bù hǎo?
examples.english: Chinese — do you speak it well?
examples.french: En chinois — tu le parles bien ?

grammar.title: Acquired Skills 會 huì
grammar.explanation: 會 (huì) is an auxiliary verb indicating a skill or ability acquired through learning. It is different from 可以 (kěyǐ), which indicates permission or possibility. Negation: 不會. Questions: 會不會...? or ...嗎?

examples.chinese: 你會做甜點嗎？我最喜歡吃甜點了。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ huì zuò tiándiǎn ma? Wǒ zuì xǐhuān chī tiándiǎn le.
examples.english: Do you know how to make desserts? I love desserts.
examples.french: Tu sais faire des desserts ? J'adore les desserts.

examples.chinese: 他不會說中文，可是他很想學。
examples.pinyin: Tā bù huì shuō Zhōngwén, kěshì tā hěn xiǎng xué.
examples.english: He can't speak Chinese, but he really wants to learn.
examples.french: Il ne sait pas parler chinois, mais il veut vraiment apprendre.

grammar.title: Destination Marker 到 dào
grammar.explanation: 到 (dào) is a preposition marking the destination of movement. The main verb of the sentence is typically 來 (come) or 去 (go). Negation is placed before 到, not before the main verb: 不到我家來. In Taiwan, 到 can also be used directly as the main verb (like 來/去).

examples.chinese: 這個週末，你到我家來吃飯，好嗎？
examples.pinyin: Zhège zhōumò, nǐ dào wǒ jiā lái chīfàn, hǎo ma?
examples.english: This weekend, come to my place for dinner, okay?
examples.french: Ce week-end, viens dîner chez moi, d'accord ?

examples.chinese: 他今天不到餐廳來，所以我們自己去。
examples.pinyin: Tā jīntiān bù dào cāntīng lái, suǒyǐ wǒmen zìjǐ qù.
examples.english: He's not coming to the restaurant today, so we'll go ourselves.
examples.french: Il ne vient pas au restaurant aujourd'hui, donc nous y allons nous-mêmes.
